address.text: King Faisal District, Al-Ahsa, Saudi Arabia

reasonCode.text: Fatigue, weight gain, and feeling cold despite summer heat

coding.display: Thyroxine (T4) free [Mass/volume] in Serum or Plasma

reasonCode.text: To determine if hypothyroidism is autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis)

note.text: Test for Anti-TPO and Anti-Thyroglobulin antibodies to confirm autoimmune etiology given family history of thyroid disease.
Recheck TSH and Free T4 in 6 weeks after starting levothyroxine to assess treatment response and adjust dosage if needed.
Dietary counseling for hypothyroidism-related weight gain. Focus on metabolism-boosting foods and portion control.

dosageInstruction.text: Take 50 mcg once daily on empty stomach, 30-60 minutes before breakfast

additionalInstruction.text: Take on empty stomach at least 30 minutes before food

dosageInstruction.text: Take 1000 IU once daily with food

reasonCode.text: Follow-up to assess levothyroxine treatment response

resource.description: 6-week follow-up to review lab results and adjust thyroid medication if needed
Blood work for TSH and Free T4 follow-up

text.div: Fatigue, weight gain, and feeling cold despite summer heat

37-year-old Saudi woman presents with 6-month history of increasing fatigue, 10kg weight gain despite unchanged diet, feeling cold when others are comfortable, dry skin, and hair thinning. Also reports constipation, heavy menstrual periods, and difficulty concentrating at work. Symptoms developed gradually after her second pregnancy 18 months ago. Family history of thyroid disease in mother. Previous normal thyroid function during pregnancy. No chest pain, palpitations, or heat intolerance. Sleep quality poor with frequent awakening.

Weight: 75kg (up from 65kg baseline). Height: 160cm. BMI: 29.3. BP: 140/85 mmHg, HR: 58 bpm, Temp: 36.2Â°C. Appears tired with puffy face and dry skin. Thyroid gland not enlarged or nodular. Slow relaxation phase of deep tendon reflexes noted. Hair appears dry and brittle. No periorbital edema. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations normal.

TSH: 12.5 mIU/L (elevated, normal 0.4-4.0)
Free T4: 0.6 ng/dL (low, normal 0.8-1.8)
Total Cholesterol: 250 mg/dL (elevated, goal <200)
Results consistent with primary hypothyroidism.

Assessment: Primary hypothyroidism, likely postpartum thyroiditis progressing to permanent hypothyroidism. Classic symptoms and laboratory findings consistent with thyroid hormone deficiency.

Plan:

  1. Start levothyroxine 50 mcg daily on empty stomach, 30-60 minutes before breakfast
  2. Thyroid antibody testing (Anti-TPO, Anti-Thyroglobulin) to confirm autoimmune etiology
  3. Recheck TSH and Free T4 in 6 weeks to assess treatment response and adjust dosage
  4. Iron supplementation 325mg daily with food for fatigue and heavy periods
  5. Vitamin D3 1000 IU daily for bone health and mood
  6. Nutritionist consultation for weight management and metabolism support
  7. Regular exercise as tolerated - start with low-impact activities
  8. Monitor for medication interactions, especially calcium and iron separation
  9. Follow-up appointment in 6 weeks with lab results
  10. Patient education on thyroid hormone replacement and lifestyle modifications

coding.display: History of family member diseases Narrative

text.div: Strong family history of thyroid disorders suggesting genetic predisposition. Mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis diagnosed in her 40s, well-controlled with levothyroxine. Maternal grandmother had goiter and suspected thyroid problems but never formally diagnosed. Younger sister recently diagnosed with hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease). Maternal aunt has hypothyroidism and diabetes. Pattern suggests autoimmune thyroid disease inheritance through maternal line.

note.text: Hashimoto's thyroiditis diagnosed at age 42 following fatigue and weight gain. Anti-TPO antibodies positive. Well-controlled on levothyroxine 75 mcg daily with regular monitoring. TSH levels maintained in normal range.

Developed visible goiter in her 50s with symptoms of fatigue and cold intolerance. Never received formal thyroid testing due to limited medical resources in rural area. Family suspects hypothyroidism based on symptoms.

Graves' disease diagnosed 2 years ago presenting with palpitations, weight loss, and anxiety. TSI antibodies positive. Currently managed with methimazole and propranolol. Considering radioactive iodine treatment.
Hypothyroidism diagnosed at age 45. Takes levothyroxine 100 mcg daily. Also has Type 2 diabetes mellitus, suggesting possible autoimmune predisposition affecting multiple endocrine organs.
Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago. Managed with metformin and lifestyle modifications. Regular endocrine follow-up for both thyroid and diabetes.
